paper_title.ja: 熱中症との戦い（２）－ある運動部の生活習慣調査－
paper_title.en: The Fight Against Heat Stroke Occurring in Athletic Clubs in a University (2) : A Questionnaire concerning the Lifestyles of Athletic Club Members

description.ja: The health center of our university has been fighting against the dangers of heat stroke since 2004. This effort has been made with the cooperation of the student affairs section. The struggle against heat stroke is tough as we realize members of athletic clubs have the mutual aim of victory and therefore often overexert during activity, even in the hottest conditions. To determine the problems associated with the lifestyles of the athletic club members, a questionnaire was assigned to 50 clubs last summer. We reported the partical results obtained from the total data received. In this paper, we analyzed in detail the data obtained from a single club, which has gained remarkable positive results concerning the problems of lifestyle. It was found that time spent sleeping was shorter than that of a senior and a freshman is hesitant to report their poor physical condition to his senior or manager. These are risk factors of heat stroke. A manager should understand them, form an exercise plan and closely watch members of the athletic club. They should be especially vigilant of signs of heatstroke in freshman players.
description.en: The health center of our university has been fighting against the dangers of heat stroke since 2004. This effort has been made with the cooperation of the student affairs section. The struggle against heat stroke is tough as we realize members of athletic clubs have the mutual aim of victory and therefore often overexert during activity, even in the hottest conditions. To determine the problems associated with the lifestyles of the athletic club members, a questionnaire was assigned to 50 clubs last summer. We reported the partical results obtained from the total data received. In this paper, we analyzed in detail the data obtained from a single club, which has gained remarkable positive results concerning the problems of lifestyle. It was found that time spent sleeping was shorter than that of a senior and a freshman is hesitant to report their poor physical condition to his senior or manager. These are risk factors of heat stroke. A manager should understand them, form an exercise plan and closely watch members of the athletic club. They should be especially vigilant of signs of heatstroke in freshman players.

paper_title.ja: NG-Methyl-L-Arginine, an Inhibitor of Nitric Oxide Synthase, Affects the Central Nervous System to Produce Peripheral Hyperglycemia in Conscious Rats(共著)
paper_title.en: N-G-methyl-L-arginine, an inhibitor of nitric oxide synthase, affects the central nervous system to produce peripheral hyperglycemia in conscious rats

description.en: To determine whether the nitric oxide (NO) system in the central nervous system (CNS) is involved in the peripheral metabolism of carbohydrate we injected N-G-methyl-L-arginine (L-NMA), an inhibitor of NO synthase, into the third cerebral ventricle of unanesthetized, unrestrained rats and determined the plasma level of glucose. This intracerebroventricular (i.c.v.) injection of the drug increased the plasma level of glucose dose-dependently, whereas an intravenous (i.v.) injection had no effect. The hyperglycemia thus induced was suppressed by concomitant i.c.v. or prior i.v. administration of L-arginine. Concomitant administration of D-arginine did not affect hyperglycemia by L-NMA. The i.c.v. injection of 5 x 10(-6) mol L-NMA increased plasma levels of glucose, epinephrine and norepinephrine, and serum levels of glucagon. However, plasma levels of insulin were unchanged, despite the presence of hyperglycemia. The hyperglycemia produced by L-NMA was completely inhibited by bilateral adrenalectomy. It was also inhibited by prior intraperitoneal injection of phentolamine, but not of propranolol or naloxone. Results suggest that L-NMA acts on the CNS to stimulate adrenal secretion of epinephrine and, subsequently, to elevate glucose levels in the peripheral blood. The NO system thus seems to be involved in the neural regulation of the adrenal by the GNS, which in turn regulates peripheral blood glucose levels.

paper_title.en: N-G-methyl-L-arginine, an inhibitor of nitric oxide synthase, affects the central nervous system to produce peripheral hyperglycemia in conscious rats

description.en: To determine whether the nitric oxide (NO) system in the central nervous system (CNS) is involved in the peripheral metabolism of carbohydrate we injected N-G-methyl-L-arginine (L-NMA), an inhibitor of NO synthase, into the third cerebral ventricle of unanesthetized, unrestrained rats and determined the plasma level of glucose. This intracerebroventricular (i.c.v.) injection of the drug increased the plasma level of glucose dose-dependently, whereas an intravenous (i.v.) injection had no effect. The hyperglycemia thus induced was suppressed by concomitant i.c.v. or prior i.v. administration of L-arginine. Concomitant administration of D-arginine did not affect hyperglycemia by L-NMA. The i.c.v. injection of 5 x 10(-6) mol L-NMA increased plasma levels of glucose, epinephrine and norepinephrine, and serum levels of glucagon. However, plasma levels of insulin were unchanged, despite the presence of hyperglycemia. The hyperglycemia produced by L-NMA was completely inhibited by bilateral adrenalectomy. It was also inhibited by prior intraperitoneal injection of phentolamine, but not of propranolol or naloxone. Results suggest that L-NMA acts on the CNS to stimulate adrenal secretion of epinephrine and, subsequently, to elevate glucose levels in the peripheral blood. The NO system thus seems to be involved in the neural regulation of the adrenal by the GNS, which in turn regulates peripheral blood glucose levels.

paper_title.ja: Increase in insulin release from rat pancreatic islets by quinolone antibiotics(共著)
paper_title.en: Increase in insulin release from rat pancreatic islets by quinolone antibiotics

description.en:
1 The present study was undertaken to elucidate the mechanism(s) of hypoglycaemia caused by quinolone antibiotics. We investigated the effects of various quinolone antibiotics on insulin release in rat pancreatic islets.
2 At a non-stimulatory concentration of 3 mM glucose, lomefloxacin (LFLX) or sparfloxacin at 1 mM and pipemidic acid (0.1-1 mM) induced slight insulin release but tosufloxacin or enoxacin up to 100 mu M did not.
3 At the stimulatory concentration of 10 mM glucose, all quinolones augmented insulin release in a dose-dependent manner. LFLX (100 mu M) shifted the dose-response curve of glucose-induced insulin release to the left without altering the maximal response.
4 At 10 mM glucose, LFLX (100 mu M) increased insulin release augmented by forskolin (5 mu M) or 12-O-tetradecanoyl phorbol-13-acetate (100 nM) but not by raising the K+ concentration from 6 to 25 mM.
5 Verapamil (50 mu M) or diazoxide (50-400 mu M) antagonized the insulinotropic effect of LFLX. 6 These data suggest that quinolone antibiotics may cause hypoglycaemia by increasing insulin release via blockade of ATP-sensitive K+ channels.

paper_title.en: Increase in insulin release from rat pancreatic islets by quinolone antibiotics

description.en:
1 The present study was undertaken to elucidate the mechanism(s) of hypoglycaemia caused by quinolone antibiotics. We investigated the effects of various quinolone antibiotics on insulin release in rat pancreatic islets.
2 At a non-stimulatory concentration of 3 mM glucose, lomefloxacin (LFLX) or sparfloxacin at 1 mM and pipemidic acid (0.1-1 mM) induced slight insulin release but tosufloxacin or enoxacin up to 100 mu M did not.
3 At the stimulatory concentration of 10 mM glucose, all quinolones augmented insulin release in a dose-dependent manner. LFLX (100 mu M) shifted the dose-response curve of glucose-induced insulin release to the left without altering the maximal response.
4 At 10 mM glucose, LFLX (100 mu M) increased insulin release augmented by forskolin (5 mu M) or 12-O-tetradecanoyl phorbol-13-acetate (100 nM) but not by raising the K+ concentration from 6 to 25 mM.
5 Verapamil (50 mu M) or diazoxide (50-400 mu M) antagonized the insulinotropic effect of LFLX. 6 These data suggest that quinolone antibiotics may cause hypoglycaemia by increasing insulin release via blockade of ATP-sensitive K+ channels.
